Induction of any sort is not advisable until 39 weeks now, unless completely medically necessary. I don't think she's being rude. Just because your baby is born healthy doesn't mean he won't experience asthma or other health conditions due to forced termination of pregnancy (induction), malnourishment, etc. Maybe we just want the best for your little one and wish you knew what we did. There is a lot of research on this, time even had a great article on nourishment (or lack of) effecting people later on in thier 50's. One of the best things you can do for your little one is give them all the time they need in the womb for nourishment and protection and breastfeeding.

Ok n what I was simply doing was asking a question, never once I said anything about trying to bring on labor. If she wasn't trying to come off rude, she could've just said it a better way. Thank you for your input as well..Blessings to the both of you!

Again if your not gonna answer the question nicely then keep your comments to yourself. Because if I was her I would report your stupid ***** for yelling!

Again don't really think it's rude. I was induced at 37 weeks, they argued with me at 36 that it was safe. I had already gained 60 pounds, my narrow hips had spread and it was so painful, my ears wouldn't stop popping, people thought I was carrying twins, and she was 10 lbs. After arguments they told me I had no option and I was getting induced... apparently they do this to 1 in 5 women. I get its uncomfortable, it just bothered me so much how my own doctors were feeding me bad science and info just Bc it was convenient for them. I don't want anyone treated or misled the way they do at my hospital. They treat women like cattle where I delivered with my first. I do not mean to offend and I guess it's a good question... now I know to not sit on the dryer... haha. God bless you too, good luck.

These tales that are mentioned to bring on labor are just that tales, but it won't hurt to try just to help things along.

Omg...it was a simple question...my baby was born at 35 weeks...nothing was wrong with her...she was 5.9 lbs...no breathing problems or anything...every pregnancy and every baby are not the same...I'm seeing doctors inducing mothers at 37 weeks and the mother/baby are completely healthy...older women use to speed things up using castor oil and their babies were fine and other techniques

This comment isn't in response to the original post but to the ensuing commentary.Anyone who is interested in a "pregnancy math check" can go read the recommendations from the ACOG and the March of Dimes, who set health standards for pregnancy and birth in the United States and abroad. It has been nearly a year since guidelines were updated to reflect enormous amounts of research proving that babies born BEFORE 39 WEEKS are at significantly increased risk of possibly major complications. Therefore 37 weeks is no longer "full term". 37-38 weeks is "early term", 39-41 weeks is "full term" and 42+ is "post-term". Induction of labor before 39 weeks without medical reasons (like IUGR, severe gestational diabetes, or life-threatening preeclampsia - not like "I'm tired of being pregnant" or "eight pounds is too big" or "but my ankles hurt") is irresponsible and unsafe. Period.Oh, and "my baby was preterm but is totally fine" doesn't mean everyone will be so lucky. That's what we call a logical fallacy and it's not a good way to make a point.

Hey, it's no skin off my nose whether or not anyone actually cares about the facts I've shared. It just makes me wonder what else your doctors are wrong or underinformed about. Keeping up with changes in major (and minor) recommendations from the boards who determine health policy is one of a doctor's most important jobs. It's a shame your doctors haven't bothered to read the research - my midwives were sharing the information with their clients as soon as the changes were made last January.Hey maybe your doctor can tell you what they think about vibration.
I think that if vibration brings on real labor your body was already close enough. I don't believe all these remedies work unless you're already on your way to full blown labor. Just saying.

Mackgirl24 I agree it's a 50/50 chance with a lot of remedies n tales. Either they work for some n some they don't. But that was the first I've heard of vibration n just thought I'd ask if it worked for anyone. N geekmom1213 you don't know if you're doctor could be guessing or not either, your doc could be right n ours could be wrong, or ours could be right n yours could be right. No way of really knowing, n no reason to really sit up here n argue about who's right n who's wrong. At the end of the day me being 37 weeks I know I'm full term n my kids are healthy so that's all that matters. So wish you all the best on your pregnancy n life God Bless hun ;)
